text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
25.4.2.4(2) Note: The OEP Main Line Phone # has changed to (313) 234-2490.
This material supersedes IRM 25.4.2, dated January 26, 2021.
All Business Operating and Functional Divisions with employees whose duties require them to have with taxpayers.
Table of Contents
Purpose: This IRM section provides information on OEP and describes Caution Upon Contact (CAU) program and CAU reporting process.
Initiating a CAU case; Reviewing and analyzing the Caution Indicator Referral Report,

, against the CAU criteria; Making a determination as to whether or not CAU criteria have met; Inputting and removing the CAU indicator to and from the Data Retrieval System (IDRS) Master File and/or Non-Master File accounts; Maintaining the CAU section of the Employee Protection System e-Trak Database; Functioning as liaison with General Legal Services (GLS); Providing information and feedback to referring employees and their spective IRS managers; Performing CAU ﬁve-year reviews.

Step Action a) Prepare a Form 13090, Caution Indicator Referral Report, ensuring the form contains: • The facts necessary to explain the incident, describing the exact words, body language or gestures made by the taxpayer; • The Taxpayer’s Social Security Number or Employer Identiﬁcation Number; and • A minimal amount of tax information and only what is necessary to establish a nexus to tax administration. b) Provide a copy of the completed Form 13090 to their immediate manager. c) Submit the Form 13090 to OEP via fax, mail, or a secure E-mail message.
Prepare a Form

, Caution Indicator Referral Report, ensuring the form contains: • The facts necessary to explain the incident, describing the exact words, body language or gestures made by the taxpayer; • The Taxpayer’s Social Security Number or Employer Identiﬁcation Number; and • A minimal amount of tax information and only what is necessary to establish a nexus to tax administration. Provide a copy of the completed Form
to their immediate manager.

a. Threat: Verbal or written expression of intent to cause harm to an IRS employee or contractor or to an IRS employee’s or contractor’s immediate family member. It also includes preventing an IRS employee or contractor from leaving a taxpayer’s business or residence, even if no physical contact actually occurs. b. Intimidate: Action intended to cause an IRS employee or contractor to become timid, or to force or deter an IRS employee or contractor from taking action. c. Nexus to Tax Administration: A taxpayer who has some type of open activity or reasonable prospect of future activity on their or their busi
ness’s IDRS Master File or Non
Master File account, or a taxpayer who, even one with no open activity or reasonable prospect of future activity, initiates contact with the Service or any other tax administration
The following table contains deﬁnitions for the acronyms used in this IRM:

Contact” Taxpayer 25.4.2 page Acronym Deﬁnition POA Power of Attorney PDT Potentially Dangerous Taxpayer ROI Report of Investigation SSN Social Security Number TIGTA Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration

Programs (
) The designation of Caution Upon Contact (CAU) must be based on reliable evidence or information. There must also be a nexus to tax administration. (
) Taxpayers must be identiﬁed by Social Security Numbers (SSN) and/or Employer Identiﬁcation Numbers (EIN). (
) A PDT designation takes precedence over a CAU designation. As a result, taxpayers who have been identiﬁed as PDT’s cannot be simultaneously nated with the CAU indicator. (

) The following criteria have been established for determining CAU status. behavior/activity/incidents at issue must have occurred within the ten-year period immediately preceding the time of classiﬁcation as Caution Upon Contact:
Individuals who, within the past
years, have threatened physical that is less severe or immediate than necessary to satisfy PDT
Individuals who, within the past
years, have threatened suicide; or
Individuals who, within the past

years, have ﬁled or threatened to a frivolous lien or a frivolous civil or criminal legal action against an employee, a former employee, a contractor, or an immediate family member of an IRS employee, a former employee, or contractor. (

) A taxpayer who meets any of the above criteria must be approached with caution. Note: The preceding criteria were approved by Chief Counsel. Adherence to the criteria is essential to ensure compliance with the Privacy Act. If a situation represents a borderline case in the application of the above the determination must be made in favor of the CAU designation (erring the side of caution) for the protection of Service employees.
The designation of Caution Upon Contact (CAU) must be based on reliable evidence or information. There must also be a nexus to tax administration.

evidence or information. There must also be a nexus to tax administration. Taxpayers must be identiﬁed by Social Security Numbers (SSN) and/or Employer Identiﬁcation Numbers (EIN). A PDT designation takes precedence over a CAU designation. As a result, taxpayers who have been identiﬁed as PDT’s cannot be simultaneously desig
nated with the CAU indicator. The following criteria have been established for determining CAU status. The behavior/activity/incidents at issue must have occurred within the ten
year period immediately preceding the time of classiﬁcation as Caution Upon Contact:
Individuals who, within the past
years, have threatened physical harm that is less severe or immediate than necessary to satisfy PDT criteria;
Individuals who, within the past
years, have threatened suicide; or
Individuals who, within the past

years, have ﬁled or threatened to ﬁle a frivolous lien or a frivolous civil or criminal legal action against an IRS employee, a former employee, a contractor, or an immediate family member of an IRS employee, a former employee, or contractor.

The preceding criteria were approved by Chief Counsel. Adherence to the criteria is essential to ensure compliance with the Privacy Act. If a particular situation represents a borderline case in the application of the above the determination must be made in favor of the CAU designation (erring on the side of caution) for the protection of Service employees.

When an IRS employee discovers a CAU indicator on a taxpayer’s account and that employee is unaware of why the taxpayer was designated as a CAU, the IRS employee may utilize the link to OEP’s EPS e-Trak Database Site at: https://etrak

web.irs.gov/etrak-privacy/page.request.do?page=eps. caf.lookup. The IRS employee is to enter the taxpayer’s SSN into the SSN search ﬁeld. The taxpayer’s information will appear along with the CAU ria met. If an IRS employee does not have access to a computer to utilize the OEP EPS e-Trak Database, the IRS employee may contact OEP to ob- tain background information on the reason(s) for the CAU designation. IRS employees may contact OEP by calling OEP’s main line at (
or sending a secure message to OEP’s mailbox *PGLD OEP.

a. The OEP Specialist will notify the referring IRS employee and his/her manager that a PDT case will be initiated on the reported incident. b. The OEP Specialist will contact the referring employee’s local Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) Field Division to begin an investigation and to initiate a PDT case.

manager that a PDT case will be initiated on the reported incident. b. The OEP Specialist will contact the referring employee’s local Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) Field Division to begin an investigation and to initiate a PDT case. (

) An IRS employee, who is assigned a case for which there is a POA and will be contact with that POA, has a “business need to know” whether the Attorney (POA) has been designated as a PDT or CAU. The IRS employee can utilize IDRS ascertain whether the POA has been designated as a PDT or a CAU, just as the IRS employee does for any taxpayer, as long as the IRS employee does not access any of the POA’s other tax information. (
) IDRS Command Code “ENMOD” can be used to determine if the POA has been designated as either a PDT or a CAU. If an IRS employee does not

) An IRS employee, who is assigned a case for which there is a POA and there will be contact with that POA, has a “business need to know” whether the POA has been designated as a PDT or CAU. The IRS employee can utilize IDRS to ascertain whether the POA has been designated as a PDT or a CAU, just as the IRS employee does for any taxpayer, as long as the IRS employee does not access any of the POA’s other tax information.
IDRS Command Code “ENMOD” can be used to determine if the POA has been designated as either a PDT or a CAU. If an IRS employee does not

know the POA’s SSN and/or EIN needed to utilize “ENMOD”, he/she can Command Codes “NAMES” or “NAMEI” to obtain the POA’s SSN - OR - “NAMEE” or “NAMEB” to obtain the POA’s EIN. For assistance in using Command Codes, please consult the “IRS Processing Codes and handbook (Document
) or other IDRS resources. (

) If an IRS employee is unable to determine if the POA has been either a PDT or a CAU utilizing IDRS, the IRS employee may utilize the OEP’s EPS e-Trak Database at: request.do?page=eps.caf.lookup. The IRS employee is to enter the POA’s Centralized Authorization File (CAF) number into the CAF Number search a. If the POA has been designated as a PDT or CAU, or if a case on POA is in Pending status, the POA’s information will appear, along the PDT or CAU criteria met, . b. If the POA has not been designated as a PDT or CAU, or if there are cases on the POA in Pending status, no information will appear. (

) If an IRS employee does not have access to a computer to utilize IDRS or OEP’s EPS e-Trak Database, the IRS employee may contact OEP. The employee will give the POA’s name, address and CAF number to an OEP cialist who will utilize OEP’s EPS e-Trak Database and determine if the has been designated as either a PDT or a CAU. (
) A CAU indicator will remain on the taxpayer’s IDRS Master File and/or Master File account for ﬁve years, at which time, the status will be of CAU by an OEP Specialist. (

) Any taxpayer who has been designated with a CAU indicator for ﬁve and who meets one or both of the following renewal criteria, will retain the CAU indicator for an additional ﬁve-year period: a. An additional CAU or PDT referral was made during the ﬁve-year under review and/or b. There is current IRS activity at the time of the review. (
) If the taxpayer does not meet the above renewal criteria, an OEP will remove the CAU indicator from that taxpayer’s IDRS Master File Non-Master File account.

know the POA’s SSN and/or EIN needed to utilize “ENMOD”, he/she can use Command Codes “NAMES” or “NAMEI” to obtain the POA’s SSN - OR - “NAMEE” or “NAMEB” to obtain the POA’s EIN. For assistance in using these Command Codes, please consult the “IRS Processing Codes and Information” handbook (Document 6209) or other IDRS resources.

If an IRS employee does not have access to a computer to utilize IDRS or OEP’s EPS e-Trak Database, the IRS employee may contact OEP. The IRS employee will give the POA’s name, address and CAF number to an OEP Spe- cialist who will utilize OEP’s EPS e-Trak Database and determine if the POA has been designated as either a PDT or a CAU.
This Page Intentionally Left Blank
Once a designation has been made, the CAU indicator will appear in the upper right-hand section of the following documents and systems:
• Microﬁlm Replacement System (MRS)Transcripts • Audit Information Management System (AIMS) • AIMS Display (AMDIS) • AIMS Weekly Updates • AIMS Charge-Out (Form

) • Federal Tax Deposit (FTD) Alerts (BMF only) • Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) Transcripts • Tax Modules (TXMOD) • Entity Modules (ENMOD) • Summary Modules (SUMRY) • Taxpayer Delinquent Inquiry (TDINQ) • Corporate Files On Line (CFOL) Modules • Individual Master File On Line (IMFOL) • Business Master File On Line (BMFOL) • Information National On Line Entity (INOLE) • Balance Due Accounts • Return Delinquency Accounts • Daily Transaction Registers (DTR’s) • Integrated Collection System (ICS) screens • Automated Collection System (ACS) Web • Examination Returns Control System (ERCS) screens
